title: Care of Environment — Sweeping
description: Introduction to sweeping as a care of the environment activity. The child learns to use a child-sized broom and dustpan to sweep a defined area, developing coordination, concentration, and responsibility for maintaining shared spaces.
instructions:
1. 'Our home is a shared space. We take care of it together. Today you'll learn to SWEEP!'
2. Present the child-sized broom and dustpan.
3. Define a small area to sweep (a section of floor, about 4x4 feet).
4. Demonstrate: hold the broom with both hands, one near the top and one in the middle.
5. Short, smooth strokes pulling TOWARD you. 'Sweep everything into the center.'
6. Demonstrate using the dustpan: hold it flat on the floor, sweep debris onto it.
7. Child practices sweeping the area. Dispose of debris in the trash.
8. 'Whenever you see something on the floor, you know what to do!'
materials_needed: Small debris to practice sweeping (torn paper bits or cracker crumbs)

slides.heading: Care of Environment
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn how to be super helpers and take care of our home, just like grown-ups do. Today, we're going to learn a special way to make the floor super clean called sweeping!

slides.setup_instructions: Scatter a small amount of torn paper bits on a section of floor. Have broom and dustpan ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these cool tools! We have a little broom, just for you, and a little dustpan to catch all the yucky stuff. And see these little bits of paper? Those are our practice pieces for sweeping! Ask your grown-up to help you find these so we can start our cleaning adventure!

slides.text: 'We take care of our home! When the floor is dirty, we can SWEEP it clean. Let me show you.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our special job today! Our home is a special place for all of us, and we all help keep it nice and tidy. Today, we're going to learn how to sweep the floor to make it sparkle!

slides.text: Hold the broom: 'Both hands — one near the top, one in the middle. Short, smooth strokes toward you.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend we're holding the broom! Put one hand up high near the top and the other hand down in the middle, like this. Now, we'll make short, gentle pushes, pulling the broom towards us.

slides.text: 'Sweep everything into the CENTER of the area. Make a little pile.' Demonstrate slow, deliberate strokes.
slides.mascot_explanation: See how we're making all the little pieces move together? We want to sweep them all into one spot right in the middle, like we're making a tiny little pile. Keep those gentle pushes going!

slides.text: 'Now the dustpan: hold it flat on the floor. Sweep the pile right onto it. Lift carefully and put in the trash!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it’s time for the magic dustpan! We hold it flat on the floor, right next to our little pile. Gently sweep all those pieces right onto the dustpan, and then we can carefully take them to the trash can!

slides.prompt: Sweep the whole area. Get every little piece into the dustpan! When you're done, check: is the floor completely clean?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's your turn to be the super sweeper! Let's try to sweep all those little bits into our dustpan. Make sure we get every single piece so our floor is all clean and shiny! You can do it!

slides.text: 'You cleaned the floor all by yourself! This is a job you can do anytime our floor needs help.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sweep debris into a pile and transfer it to a dustpan without scattering it?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You swept the floor all by yourself and made it so clean. Now you know how to help take care of our home anytime you see little messes. Great job being such a good helper!

parent_notes: Care of the environment is a fundamental Montessori practical life category. Sweeping teaches the child that maintaining shared spaces is everyone's responsibility, not just the adults'. Use a real child-sized broom (not a toy) — the child can tell the difference and takes real tools seriously. The key skill is the sweeping direction: always TOWARD the body, always into a central pile. Most children initially sweep in all directions, scattering debris. Patient demonstration helps. Once learned, sweeping becomes a daily routine the child can do independently, building self-discipline and contribution to family life.

title: Q1 Sound Review — All Letters Learned
description: Comprehensive review of all letter sounds learned in Quarter 1. The child demonstrates mastery of approximately 15 sandpaper letters and the 'sh' phonogram through tracing, sound identification, and word building.
instructions:
1. Lay out ALL learned sandpaper letters: s, m, a, t, p, r, i, o, n, g, l, h, d, b (and sh phonogram).
2. 'Let's see how many sounds you know! I'll point to a letter — you tell me its sound.'
3. Go through each letter. Note any that need review.
4. Reverse: 'I'll say a sound — you find the letter!' /m/... /g/... /sh/...
5. Speed round: lay out 6 letters. Child traces and says each as fast as they can (accuracy over speed).
6. Word building challenge: 'Build as many words as you can in 5 minutes!' Child works independently.
7. Count the words together. Celebrate the total!

slides.heading: Q1 Sound Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is our special page all about the letter sounds you learned. We're going to remember all the super cool sounds letters make!

slides.setup_instructions: Spread all learned letters on the mat. Have moveable alphabet ready for word building.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special learning tools ready! We have our bumpy sandpaper letters that feel so nice to touch, and we have little letter pieces to build words. We'll need all of them for our fun game!

slides.text: 'Look at all the letters you've learned! Let's review every one.' Point to each — child says the sound.
slides.mascot_explanation: See all these letters? You know them all! I'm going to point to one, and you tell me the sound it makes. It's like a guessing game, and you're so good at it!

slides.text: Reverse: 'Find the letter that says /p/!' Child picks it up. '/sh/!' Child finds the phonogram.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, it's my turn to be a little tricky! I'll say a sound, and you have to be a super detective and find the letter that makes that sound. Can you find the letter for /sh/?

slides.text: Note any letters the child hesitates on. 'Let's trace this one three more times to make it stick.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, a few letters felt a little shy today, and that's okay! We can practice tracing them together a few more times. This helps your brain remember them so they don't feel tricky anymore!

slides.text: 'Now the fun part — build as many WORDS as you can! Use any letters you know.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part! We get to play a word-building game! You can use all the letters you know to make little words, like "at" or "in." Let's see what amazing words you can create!

slides.prompt: Word building challenge! Build as many words as you can in 5 minutes. Each word gets a tally mark. How many can you make?
slides.mascot_explanation: We have five whole minutes to build as many words as you can! Every time you make a word, we'll put a little mark. Can you make tons and tons of words? I bet you can!

slides.text: 'You know so many sounds and can build so many words! You've made incredible progress this quarter!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify at least 12 of the 15 letter sounds without hesitation?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You remembered so many letter sounds and built so many words! You are such a super learner, and I'm so proud of you for all the amazing work you did this quarter!

parent_notes: This review lesson gives you a clear picture of where the child stands at the end of Q1. Note which letters are automatic (immediate recognition) and which still require effort. Letters that need effort should be revisited daily until they become automatic. The word building challenge is both assessment and celebration — the child sees how many words they can now create from the sounds they've learned. A typical Q1 child might build 10-20 words in 5 minutes. Record this number; you'll compare it at the end of Q2 to show growth.

title: Q1 Math Review — Number Rods and Counting
description: Review of foundational math concepts from Quarter 1: number rods 1-10, one-to-one correspondence, counting with understanding, and the concept of zero. Assessing mastery before moving to Q2.
instructions:
1. Lay out all number rods in stair formation (1-10).
2. 'Point to each rod and count.' Child counts segments: 1, 2, 3... up to 10.
3. Random: 'Hand me the rod that shows 7.' 'Which rod shows 4?'
4. Match sandpaper numerals to rods: child places the correct numeral beside each rod.
5. Counting objects: give the child 10 small objects. 'Count out exactly 6.' Then 8. Then 3.
6. Zero: 'Count out zero objects.' (Nothing!) 'Zero means none.'
7. Addition preview: 'What's 3 and 2?' Child combines rods. 'Five!'

slides.heading: Q1 Math Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It says "Q1 Math Review," which means we get to play with all the fun math things we learned in the first part of school. We're going to see numbers, count things, and play with special counting sticks!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up rods in stair formation. Have numerals and counting objects ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our special math toys ready! See these long colorful sticks? Those are our Number Rods, and they help us see how numbers grow. We also have bumpy number cards called Sandpaper Numerals, and then some little toys for counting. Ask a grown-up to help you get them all out and put the rods in a special stair shape!

slides.text: 'Let's visit all our number friends! Count the rods: 1, 2, 3... all the way to 10.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's say hello to our number friends! We're going to point to each of these colorful rods, one by one, and count how many little parts they have. We'll count 1, then 2, then 3, all the way up to the biggest one that has 10 parts!

slides.text: Random requests: 'Show me 7!' 'Hand me 4!' Child selects the correct rod each time.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a fun game of "I Spy" with numbers! I'll ask you to find a number, like "Show me 7!" and you'll point to the rod that has 7 little parts. Then I might ask you to hand me the rod that shows the number 4. You're going to be a super number detective!

slides.text: 'Now match the NUMBERS to the rods.' Child places sandpaper numerals beside the correct rods.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to match our bumpy number cards to the rods. Find the rod that has 5 little parts, and then find the bumpy card that feels like the number 5 and put it right next to it. We'll do this for all the numbers so they know they're friends!

slides.text: 'Count out exactly 6 objects.' Child counts carefully, one by one. Repeat with different quantities.
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to play with our little counting toys! I'm going to ask you to count out a specific number of toys, like "Can you count out 6 toys for me?" You'll pick them up one by one and count them carefully. Then we'll try another number, like 8 or 3!

slides.prompt: Match all numerals to rods. Count out 5 different quantities I request. Then show me: what's 4 and 1?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's put everything together for one big math adventure! We'll match all the bumpy numbers to their rods, count out the toy amounts I ask for, and then we'll even try a little bit of adding. You'll show me what 4 and 1 makes by putting their rods together!

slides.text: 'You know your numbers from 0 to 10 inside and out! You can count, match, and even add. What a mathematician!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count to 10, match numerals to quantities, and count out specific amounts accurately?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You are such a super mathematician! You showed me all your numbers from 0 to 10, you can count so well, and you even know how to add! You were amazing at matching the numbers and counting out the toys!

parent_notes: This review assesses the foundational skills that everything in Q2 builds upon: counting with meaning (not just reciting), numeral recognition, one-to-one correspondence (counting objects accurately), and the concept of zero. A child who can do all of these confidently is ready for Q2. If you notice gaps — for example, the child consistently miscounts objects by skipping or double-counting — spend extra time on that specific skill before moving forward. In Montessori, mastery matters more than pace.

title: Q1 Geography Review — Continents and Land/Water Forms
description: Review of all geography concepts from Quarter 1: the seven continents, land and water forms, and the child's growing understanding of our planet. Using the Continent Book as a review tool.
instructions:
1. Start with the globe. 'Can you name all seven continents?' Child points to each.
2. Review colors: North America (orange), South America (pink), Europe (red), Asia (yellow), Africa (green), Australia (brown/orange), Antarctica (white).
3. Open the Continent Book: review each page the child has created.
4. Land/water forms: 'What's an island? A peninsula? An isthmus?' Use the miniature models or globe.
5. 'What's your favorite continent? Why?'
6. Globe game: 'I'm thinking of a continent that has the biggest desert...' (Africa!) Child finds it.
7. Add a final page to the Continent Book: draw the whole world with all 7 continents labeled.

slides.heading: Q1 Geography Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Our Amazing World." That means we're going to talk all about our big, beautiful planet Earth today!

slides.setup_instructions: Have the globe, puzzle map, and the child's Continent Book all available.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to use our special learning toys! We have the big round globe, a fun puzzle map of the whole world, your super cool Continent Book, and colorful pencils to draw with. Let's get them all ready so we can play!

slides.text: 'Spin the globe! Can you name all seven continents? Point to each one as you say it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's give the globe a little spin! Can you point to all the big pieces of land called continents? Let's say their names together as you find them.

slides.text: Review land forms: 'What's an island? Show me on the globe.' 'What's a peninsula?' Child explains.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pretend we're explorers looking at the land and water! Can you show me a place that's all water surrounded by land, like a little water jewel? That's an island!

slides.text: Open the Continent Book: 'Look at all you've learned! Tell me one thing about each continent.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Open up your special Continent Book! Look at all the pages you made. Tell me something fun you remember about each place we learned about.

slides.text: Clue game: 'This continent has kangaroos!' (Australia!) 'This continent is covered in ice!' (Antarctica!)
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time for a guessing game! I'm thinking of a continent where kangaroos hop all around. Which one do you think it is? And can you find the continent that's super cold and covered in snow?

slides.prompt: Draw a world map showing all 7 continents. Color each one. Label them if you can! Add this to your Continent Book.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's draw our very own map of the whole world! We'll draw all the continents we learned about and color them in. You can even try to write their names, just like a super artist!

slides.text: 'You know so much about our world! Seven continents, land and water forms, animals, and landmarks. Amazing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and locate all 7 continents and define at least 2 land/water forms?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today! You know all about the seven continents and how to find them, and you remembered what islands are. You are a super geography star!

parent_notes: This review reveals how much geographic knowledge the child has absorbed in just 8 weeks. Most children can name and locate at least 5-6 continents confidently by this point. The Continent Book is a wonderful artifact of learning — flip through it together and admire the child's work. The clue game (describing a continent and having the child guess) is both fun and revealing of what facts have stuck. If the child struggles with a continent, revisit it casually over the coming week rather than drilling. Geographic knowledge builds best through repeated, joyful exposure.

title: Read-Aloud: Make Way for Ducklings
description: Reading Robert McCloskey's beloved story about a family of ducks navigating the streets of Boston to reach the Public Garden. A story about family, safety, and finding your place.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'Mr. and Mrs. Mallard are ducks looking for a safe place to raise their family.'
2. Read the story. Point out the lovely sepia-toned illustrations.
3. Name the ducklings together: Jack, Kack, Lack, Mack, Nack, Ouack, Pack, Quack.
4. The exciting part: the ducklings walk through Boston traffic! 'Michael the policeman stopped all the cars!'
5. After reading: 'Why did Mrs. Mallard want a safe place? What makes a good home?'
6. Count the ducklings: 'How many babies did Mr. and Mrs. Mallard have?' (8!)
7. Connection: 'Just like Mrs. Mallard, YOUR parents want a safe, wonderful place for you.'
materials_needed: Make Way for Ducklings by Robert McCloskey

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Make Way for Ducklings by Robert McCloskey
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this pretty picture! It's the cover of our special book, "Make Way for Ducklings." This story is about some ducks who are looking for a cozy and safe place to have their babies.

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably. This longer book may take 15 minutes to read.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the book we'll read together! We need to find this special book to start our adventure with the duck family. Can you help me find it? Maybe ask your grown-up to get it ready for us!

slides.text: Cover: 'The Mallards are looking for a home. They need somewhere SAFE for their babies.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the front of the book! It shows us that Mr. and Mrs. Mallard, who are ducks, need to find a super safe place for their little ducklings when they hatch. We need to remember they are looking for a safe home.

slides.text: Read with expression. When the ducklings hatch: 'Let's learn all their names: Jack, Kack, Lack, Mack...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story! Listen carefully as I read, and when the baby ducks pop out, we'll all say their funny names together, like Jack, Kack, and Lack! It's going to be so much fun!

slides.text: The traffic scene: 'Mrs. Mallard marched right into the street! Michael the policeman stopped all the cars!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh my goodness, look at this busy picture! The mama duck is walking in the street, and a nice policeman is helping stop all the cars so she can be safe. It shows how everyone helped the ducks!

slides.prompt: Can you remember all eight ducklings' names? Count them! Why did the whole city help the ducks cross the road?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's remember all the baby ducks! Can you count them with me? There are so many! And why do you think everyone in the whole city stopped to help them? They must have really cared!

slides.text: 'The Mallards found the perfect home. Everyone in the city helped because they cared about the little family.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the main events and explain why the Mallards needed a safe home?
slides.mascot_explanation: The duck family found a wonderful, safe home, and it's all because everyone helped them feel welcome. Just like the ducks, your grown-ups want to keep you safe and happy in your home too! You did a great job listening!

parent_notes: This 1941 Caldecott Medal winner is a longer read-aloud that builds listening stamina. The eight duckling names follow a rhyming pattern (Jack, Kack, Lack...) that delights children and builds phonemic awareness. The story's themes — parents protecting children, community helping families, finding a safe home — resonate deeply. If you live near a park with ducks, a follow-up nature walk to observe real duck families would be wonderful. The book also teaches about maps and navigation in an age-appropriate way. In Boston, there are actual bronze duck statues in the Public Garden!

title: Q1 Sensorial Review — Pink Tower and Brown Stair Combination
description: Review of key sensorial materials by combining the Pink Tower and Brown Stair in creative ways. The child explores how these two materials relate to each other, discovering that the pink tower cubes and brown stair prisms share a common dimension.
instructions:
1. Build the Pink Tower: largest cube at the bottom, smallest at the top. Child works from memory.
2. Build the Brown Stair: thickest prism on the left, thinnest on the right.
3. 'Now let's do something NEW — combine them!' Demonstrate: the width of each brown prism matches a pink cube.
4. Match: place the 10cm brown prism next to the 10cm pink cube. Continue matching.
5. Creative building: 'Can you make a wall? A city? A pattern using both materials?'
6. Extensions: build the pink tower on top of the brown stair. Alternate cubes and prisms.
7. Discuss: 'What's the same about these two materials? What's different?'

slides.heading: Sensorial Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It has a special name for our game today: "Pink Tower Meets Brown Stair." That means we get to play with two of our favorite building toys together and see what cool things we can make!

slides.setup_instructions: Clear a large workspace. Both materials need to be fully available.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our fun building time, we need a few things. See the big blocks that make a tower? That's the Pink Tower! And look at these long, flat pieces – that's the Brown Stair. We also need a big, soft mat to build on so all our pieces stay safe. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find them?

slides.text: 'Build the Pink Tower — you know how! Biggest at the bottom, smallest at the top.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to build the Pink Tower! You're so good at this. Remember, we put the biggest, fattest block on the bottom, and then we stack the smaller ones all the way up to the tippy-top. Let's build it from memory, just like you know how!

slides.text: 'Now build the Brown Stair — thickest on the left, thinnest on the right.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, let's build the Brown Stair. This one is a little different. We put the widest, thickest piece on this side, and then we make them thinner and thinner as we move across. It's like a staircase, but flat!

slides.text: 'Here's something cool: the brown prisms and pink cubes are RELATED! This prism is the same width as this cube!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? These toys have a secret connection! See this brown piece? It's the same width as one of the pink blocks. They are like best friends who are the same size in one way!

slides.text: 'Match each brown prism to the pink cube that's the same size. See? They go together!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a matching game! We need to find the pink block that's exactly the same size as each brown piece. We put them right next to each other so we can see they are twins! It's like finding pairs.

slides.prompt: Now create! Build something amazing using BOTH the Pink Tower and Brown Stair together. A city? A bridge? A pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the super fun part – let's build something new using both the Pink Tower and the Brown Stair! Maybe we can make a tall city, or a long bridge, or even a cool pattern. What amazing thing can you imagine and build with both of them?

slides.text: 'The Pink Tower and Brown Stair are connected — they share the same sizes! You discovered their secret relationship.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build both materials independently and match corresponding pieces?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You learned that the Pink Tower blocks and the Brown Stair pieces are connected because they have the same sizes. You built both towers and stairs and found their matching pairs – that’s amazing! You are such a super builder!

parent_notes: Combining materials is an advanced Montessori extension that reveals deep mathematical relationships. The Pink Tower cubes and Brown Stair prisms share a common dimension: the width of each brown prism matches one face of a corresponding pink cube. This isn't something you need to explain — the child discovers it through matching. Creative building with both materials develops spatial reasoning, balance, and aesthetic sense. If the child's tower or stair is imperfect, resist correcting — they'll notice the error when it doesn't look right and self-correct. This combination work marks the child's growing mastery.

title: Reading Assessment — CVC Words and Sentences
description: A gentle, low-pressure assessment of the child's reading progress. The child reads word lists, sentence strips, and short passages to demonstrate their current decoding and comprehension abilities.
instructions:
1. 'Today is a special day — you're going to show me everything you can read!'
2. Word list 1 (known CVC words): cat, dog, sit, hop, pin, rug, map, log. Child reads aloud.
3. Word list 2 (new CVC words not previously practiced): bun, fig, cob, gap, hid, jot. Can the child decode new words?
4. Sentence strips: 'A dog sat on a log.' 'Tom got a big hat.' 'The cat hid in a bag.'
5. Listen for: accurate decoding, self-correction, and blending fluency.
6. Record which words and sentences were read correctly.
7. Celebrate: 'Look how much you can read! Let's count all the words you read today!'
materials_needed: Prepared word lists (known and new CVC words)

slides.heading: Reading Celebration
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Reading Celebration"! That means we get to have a super fun party to show off all the amazing reading you can do. You're going to do great!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare word lists and sentences in advance. Make this feel like a celebration, not a test.
slides.mascot_explanation: We have some special papers here for our reading celebration! We have lists of words, like little games, and some sentences to read too. These help us practice reading together.

slides.text: 'You've learned so much! Today I want to see all the words you can read. This is going to be fun!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is a super special day because you get to show me all the cool words and sentences you know how to read! It's like a game to see how much you've learned, and it's going to be so much fun!

slides.text: Show word list 1 (familiar words). Child reads each aloud. Celebrate each success.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these words on this paper! These are words you've seen before, like "cat" and "dog." Let's try reading them together, just take your time. You're doing so well!

slides.text: Show word list 2 (new words). 'You haven't seen these before. Sound them out!' Note which strategies the child uses.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, these words are new! We haven't practiced them yet, so let's try to sound them out together. It's like being a word detective, figuring out what they say!

slides.text: Sentence strips: 'Now try these sentences!' Child reads each one. Discuss what each sentence means.
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to read some sentences now, like little stories! See if you can read each one, and then we can talk about what it means. You're getting so good at this!

slides.prompt: Read through both word lists and all the sentences. Take your time — sound out any tricky words. I'll keep count!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's read all the words and sentences we have! Take your time and sound out any words that seem a little tricky. I'll be right here to help and I'll keep track of all the awesome reading you do.

slides.text: 'You read [X] words and [X] sentences today! That's incredible progress. You are officially a READER!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read at least 75% of known CVC words and decode at least 3 new CVC words?
slides.mascot_explanation: You read so many words and sentences today – that's amazing! You are such a super reader now, and I'm so proud of all your hard work!

parent_notes: Frame this as a 'reading celebration,' not a test. The child should feel proud, not anxious. What you're actually assessing: (1) Can the child read previously practiced words? (2) Can the child decode NEW words using known sounds? The second question is crucial — it shows whether the child has internalized the phonetic principle (letters make sounds, sounds blend into words) or has merely memorized specific words. Record the results to compare with the Q2 assessment. Most children at this stage can read 15-25 CVC words and simple sentences. Whatever the number, celebrate it genuinely.

title: Q1 Math Review — Spindle Box and Cards and Counters
description: Review of the Spindle Box (0-9) and Cards and Counters materials. Assessing the child's understanding of quantity, numeral recognition, one-to-one correspondence, and the concept of odd and even.
instructions:
1. Present the Spindle Box. Child fills compartments 0-9 with correct quantities.
2. Pay attention to zero: 'What goes in the zero compartment?' (Nothing!)
3. Check: does the child count accurately? Bundle with rubber bands.
4. Switch to Cards and Counters: child lays out numeral cards 1-10 in order.
5. Place counters in pairs below each numeral.
6. 'Which numbers have a leftover counter? Which ones are all paired up?'
7. Review vocabulary: 'Numbers where every counter has a partner are EVEN. Numbers with one left over are ODD.'
8. Name all evens: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10. All odds: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9.
materials_needed: Cards and Counters (numeral cards 1-10 and 55 counters)

slides.heading: Q1 Math Review
slides.subheading: Spindle Box and Cards and Counters
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we're going to do some super fun math today! We're going to play with a special box and some little cards with numbers on them. It's like a game to help our brains get even smarter!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up both materials. Start with the Spindle Box.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these cool things we need for our math adventure! We have a special box with little sticks called spindles, and some number cards and little circles called counters. We'll also use a mat to keep everything neat. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find these for our game?

slides.text: 'Fill the Spindle Box! How many spindles go in the 0 compartment? The 1? The 2?' Child works through 0-9.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's play with the spindle box! See the little holes? We need to put the right number of sticks in each hole, starting with zero, which means nothing goes in there! Then we put one stick in the next hole, two sticks in the one after that, and we keep going all the way to nine. You can do it!

slides.text: Check each compartment together. 'Did you get the right amount in each one? Let's count!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's check our work together! We'll count the sticks in each little hole to make sure we put the perfect number in. If we have the right amount, we'll put a little rubber band around them to keep them together. Great job counting!

slides.text: Cards and Counters: 'Lay out the numbers 1 to 10. Now place counters in PAIRS below each card.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to use our number cards and little counters! We'll put the number cards in a straight line, starting with 1 and going all the way to 10. Then, under each number card, we'll put that many little counters, like little friends standing together.

slides.text: 'Look! Some numbers have all partners. Some have one left over. Which are which?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look closely at our counters! Some numbers have all their little counter friends standing in pairs, like they are holding hands. Other numbers have one little counter friend all by itself. Can you see which ones have a partner and which one is all alone?

slides.prompt: Complete both activities. Then tell me: which numbers are even (all paired)? Which are odd (one left over)?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to be math detectives! We'll figure out which numbers have all their counters in pairs – those are called EVEN numbers. And we'll find the numbers where one counter is all by itself – those are called ODD numbers. You're learning such important new words!

slides.text: 'You know your numbers perfectly — counting, zero, odd, even. Your math brain is growing strong!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately fill the Spindle Box and identify odd and even numbers with Cards and Counters?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job with the spindle box and the counters! You counted so well, and you figured out all the odd and even numbers. Your math brain is growing bigger and stronger every day, just like a superhero!

parent_notes: These two materials assess different but complementary skills. The Spindle Box tests counting and one-to-one correspondence (can the child count out exactly the right number of spindles?). Cards and Counters tests numeral recognition AND the odd/even concept. Watch for counting errors: children who skip numbers or double-count need more practice with smaller quantities first. The zero compartment is important — it should remain empty, and the child should be able to explain why. If odd/even is still unclear, that's fine — it will be revisited throughout Q2.

title: Q1 Science Review — Bean Plant Journal and Living Things
description: Reviewing the bean plant journal (started in Week 7), observing growth progress, and reviewing key science concepts from Q1: living vs. non-living, sink or float, magnetism, and states of matter.
instructions:
1. Check the bean plant! 'Look how it's grown since we planted it! Draw today's observation in your journal.'
2. 'What does our plant need to stay alive?' (Water, sunlight, air) 'That's because it's LIVING!'
3. Review living vs. non-living: child sorts 6-8 picture cards into living and non-living.
4. Review sink/float: 'Remember our experiment? What sinks? What floats? Why?'
5. Review magnets: 'What do magnets attract? What happens when you put two magnets together?'
6. Review states of matter: 'Name something solid, something liquid, something gas.'
7. Science journal: draw or write one thing learned from each science topic this quarter.

slides.heading: Q1 Science Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this slide! It says "Q1 Science Review," which means we get to look back at all the super cool science things we learned in the first part of school. We're going to remember all our discoveries together!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather the bean plant and all science journals. Prepare living/non-living picture cards.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our science stuff ready! We need our little bean plant to see how it's growing, our plant journal to draw in, some special picture cards, our science journal for drawing, and our colorful crayons. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things?

slides.text: 'Let's check our bean plant! How has it changed?' Child draws today's observation in the plant journal.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to look at our bean plant! Remember when we planted it? Let's see how much taller it's gotten and if it has new leaves. Then, we'll draw what it looks like today in our plant journal, just like a real scientist!

slides.text: Sort picture cards: 'Is a rock living or non-living? A flower? A cloud? A fish?' Child explains reasoning.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to play a sorting game with these picture cards! We need to look at each picture and decide if it's something living, like a puppy, or non-living, like a toy car. We'll talk about why we think each one belongs in its special group.

slides.text: 'What did we learn about magnets?' Child explains attract/repel. 'What about sink and float?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's think about our exciting science experiments! Do you remember how magnets work? We'll talk about what they like to stick to and what happens when we try to push two magnets together. We'll also remember what things like to sink down and what things like to float on top of the water!

slides.text: 'Name the three states of matter.' Child says solid, liquid, gas. 'Give an example of each!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned about different ways things can be, like solid, liquid, and gas. Can you think of something that's solid, like your teddy bear? And what about a liquid, like juice? We'll also think of something that's a gas, like the air we breathe.

slides.prompt: In your science journal, draw one picture for each topic: living things, magnets, sink/float, states of matter. Label each one!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to show off what we learned in our science journal! We'll draw one picture for each thing we talked about today: living things, magnets, sinking and floating, and the different ways things can be. Make sure to label each picture so we know what it is!

slides.text: 'You're a real scientist! You observe, experiment, and explain. Keep asking questions about the world!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain at least 3 of the 4 science topics reviewed with reasonable accuracy?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You are such an amazing scientist, looking closely at things and figuring out how they work. We learned so much together, and I can't wait to see what other cool things we discover next!

parent_notes: This review isn't about perfect recall — it's about seeing which concepts have truly taken root. Children often surprise us by remembering vivid details from experiments (the magnet snapping to the refrigerator, the penny sinking) while forgetting vocabulary. That's normal and good — the experience matters more than the terminology at this age. The bean plant journal is a living document of scientific observation, and seeing the plant's growth over 2+ weeks makes the concept of 'living things' very real. Continue the plant journal into Q2.

title: Q1 Art Review — Mixed Media Self-Portrait
description: A culminating art project combining techniques learned throughout Q1: drawing, painting, collage, and color mixing. The child creates a mixed-media self-portrait that showcases their artistic growth.
instructions:
1. 'Today you'll make a portrait of YOURSELF using all the art techniques we've learned!'
2. Start with a pencil drawing of the face and body on large paper.
3. Paint the background using watercolors (wet-on-wet for a dreamy effect).
4. Use crayons or pastels for the face and details.
5. Add collage elements: cut paper for clothing, yarn for hair.
6. Mix colors to match skin tone and eye color as closely as possible.
7. Display the finished portrait proudly. 'This shows YOU and your art skills!'

slides.heading: Q1 Art Celebration
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Q1 Art Celebration," which means we get to celebrate all the cool art things we learned in the first part of the year. Today, we're going to make a special picture of YOU, called a self-portrait, using lots of different art supplies!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up all materials. Place a mirror where the child can see themselves. Protect the workspace.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what we need for our amazing art project! We have big paper to draw on, a pencil for drawing, colorful watercolors, crayons for adding details, special paper and yarn for collage, scissors to cut, and glue to stick everything. We also have a mirror so we can look at our own happy faces! Go find all these things with a grown-up helper.

slides.text: 'Look in the mirror! Today you're going to make a picture of YOU using ALL the art tools we've learned.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Take a peek in the mirror, friend! See your wonderful face? Today, we're going to make a picture that looks just like you, using all the super fun art tools we've been playing with. It's going to be a picture of YOU!

slides.text: 'Start with pencil: draw your face shape, eyes, nose, mouth. Look in the mirror to see the details!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's use our pencil to draw our face. Look in the mirror again, and see your eyes, your nose, and your mouth. Draw those shapes on the paper, just like you see them. You can draw your whole body too!

slides.text: 'Paint the background with watercolors. Remember wet-on-wet? Make it colorful!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we get to paint! We'll use the watercolors to paint the background behind you. Remember how we make the colors all swirly and dreamy when the paper is wet? Let's make a beautiful, colorful background for our picture.

slides.text: 'Add color to your face with crayons. Cut paper for your clothes. Glue on yarn for hair if you'd like!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to add more fun stuff! Use your crayons to color in your face and add special details. Then, we can cut out some pretty paper for your clothes and even glue on some soft yarn for your hair if you like!

slides.prompt: Create your self-portrait! Use at least 3 different materials: paint, crayons, AND collage. Take your time and make it beautiful.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super fun part where we put it all together! We're going to make our self-portrait using paint, crayons, and even the collage bits. Take your time and make your picture look amazing, just like you!

slides.text: 'This portrait shows YOU — made with your own hands using so many techniques. You are a true artist!'
slides.mastery_check: Does the portrait demonstrate use of multiple media and attention to self-observation?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your beautiful picture! You made a picture of YOU using so many different art things – paint, crayons, and collage! You did such a great job looking at yourself and using all your new art skills. You are a wonderful artist!

parent_notes: A self-portrait is a classic art assessment because it reveals both technical skill and self-awareness. At this age, expect symbolic rather than realistic drawing — a circle head, stick body, big eyes. That's developmentally perfect. What matters is whether the child can use multiple media (paint, crayon, collage) and make conscious choices about color and detail. The mirror is essential: looking at their own features builds observation skills and self-awareness. Display this portrait somewhere prominent. It becomes a treasured keepsake and a benchmark for comparison later in the year.

title: Care of Environment — Wiping a Table
description: Learning to wipe and clean a table surface. A foundational care of environment skill that the child can use daily after meals and art activities. The precise sequence of movements develops order and thoroughness.
instructions:
1. 'After we eat or do art, the table needs cleaning. I'll show you how!'
2. Materials: sponge, spray bottle with water (or bucket with soapy water), dry cloth.
3. Demonstrate: spray the table surface lightly (or wring the sponge and wipe).
4. Wipe in organized strokes: start at the top left, wipe across to the right, move down, wipe across.
5. 'We go in rows — just like reading! Top to bottom, left to right.'
6. After wet wiping, dry with the cloth using the same pattern.
7. Child practices on their own table or section.
8. Check by running a hand across: 'Is it dry? Is it clean? Are there any sticky spots?'
materials_needed: Spray bottle with water or small bucket with soapy water

slides.heading: Care of Environment
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn how to make our tables super clean and tidy. It's like being a little helper for our room!

slides.setup_instructions: Lightly dirty the table (a few crumbs or drops of water) so there's something visible to clean.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these helpers we have for cleaning! We have a soft sponge to wipe, a spray bottle to make it a little wet, and a soft cloth to make it all dry. We need these to make our table sparkle!

slides.text: 'A clean table is a happy table! First, spray a little water.' (Or wring the sponge so it's damp, not dripping.)
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first we need to make the table a little bit wet so we can clean it. We'll use our spray bottle to give it a little spritz, or we can use our sponge if it's just a little bit damp.

slides.text: 'Wipe in ROWS: start at the top, go across, move down a little, go across again. Like reading!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's wipe the table in neat rows, just like we read a book! We go side to side, then move down a little bit, and go side to side again. This way, we don't miss any spots!

slides.text: 'Now dry it with the cloth. Same pattern: rows from top to bottom.' Feel with your hand: 'Is it dry?'
slides.mascot_explanation: All done with the wet wiping? Great! Now we get our dry cloth and do the same thing – wiping in neat rows to make sure everything is super dry. Let's run our hand over it to check!

slides.prompt: Clean the table yourself! Spray, wipe in rows, then dry. Check with your hand — is every part clean and dry?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's your turn to be the table cleaner! You get to spray, wipe in your neat rows, and then dry it all up. Make sure you check with your hand to see if it's all clean and dry!

slides.text: 'You can clean your own table now! After every meal and art time, you know exactly what to do.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child wipe a table systematically (in rows) and verify it's clean and dry?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are a fantastic table cleaner now! You know how to make our tables so nice and tidy after we eat or play. You're such a good helper!

parent_notes: Table wiping seems simple, but the Montessori approach teaches it with deliberate precision: organized rows, left to right, top to bottom. This pattern mirrors the reading direction and builds the same left-to-right tracking that reading requires. Children who learn to clean systematically also develop thoroughness — a habit that transfers to academic work. The spray bottle itself is good for hand strength. After this lesson, the child should be expected to wipe their own place at the table after every meal. This isn't a chore; it's a contribution and a source of pride.

title: Writing Practice — Sand Tray and Paper
description: Review of letter formation through sand tray writing and transition to pencil-on-paper writing. The child practices writing known letters, connecting the motor memory from sandpaper letters to independent writing.
instructions:
1. Sand tray: child writes each known letter in sand while saying the sound.
2. Go through all letters: s, m, a, t, p, r, i, o, n, g, l, h, d, b.
3. 'Now let's try on paper!' Provide lined paper with dotted midline.
4. Demonstrate: write each letter slowly, narrating the strokes.
5. Child traces dotted letters, then writes independently.
6. Don't correct letter formation harshly — focus on the sounds: 'What sound does that letter make?'
7. Write their name.
8. Extension: write 2-3 CVC words on paper.

slides.heading: Writing Practice
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to practice writing today! We'll start by writing in the sand, and then we'll try writing on paper, just like a big kid!

slides.setup_instructions: Smooth the sand tray. Have lined paper and a well-sharpened pencil ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we have for writing! We have a tray with soft sand, some special paper with lines, and a pencil to draw with. We also have some letters made of scratchy paper to help us remember how to make them.

slides.text: 'Write each letter in the sand. Say its sound as you write it.' Child goes through all known letters.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's get our hands a little messy and have some fun! We're going to draw letters in the sand with our fingers, and as we draw each one, we'll say the sound it makes. Can you remember the sounds the letters make?

slides.text: 'Now the exciting part — writing on PAPER with a pencil!' Show how to hold the pencil with three fingers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, now it's time to write with a pencil! This is super exciting! We'll hold our pencil with our fingers, like this, so we can make nice, neat letters.

slides.text: Demonstrate: write the letter 's' slowly. 'Start at the top, curve around...' Child tries below.
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me, I'm going to show you how to make the letter 's'. See? We start at the top and make a little curve. Now you try it right below where I drew it!

slides.text: 'Write as many letters as you can. If you forget how one looks, check the sandpaper letter!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to write lots of letters on our paper now. If you forget how to make a letter, don't worry! You can look at those scratchy sandpaper letters to help you remember.

slides.prompt: Write all the letters you know on paper. Then write your name! If you can, write 2 CVC words: cat, dog, sun.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to show off! Write all the letters you know on the paper, and then try writing your name! If you're feeling super brave, you can even try writing words like "cat" or "dog."

slides.text: 'You can WRITE! First in sand, now on paper. Writing lets you share your thoughts with the world!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write at least 10 recognizable letters and attempt their name?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You are such a super writer! You learned to make letters in the sand and then on paper, and that's amazing. Writing helps us share all our wonderful ideas with everyone!

parent_notes: In Montessori, reading and writing develop together, but writing actually often comes first because the child has been tracing sandpaper letters (a writing activity) since the beginning. The transition from sand to paper is significant. Use triangular pencils or pencil grips to encourage the proper three-finger (tripod) grip. Lined paper with a dotted midline helps with letter sizing. Do NOT expect perfection — reversed letters, inconsistent sizes, and wobbly lines are all completely normal. What matters is that the child connects the sound to the written symbol. Praise effort and sound knowledge over penmanship.

title: Q1 Math Review — Teen Board, Ten Board, and Hundred Board
description: Comprehensive review of place value materials introduced in weeks 7-8. The child demonstrates understanding of teen numbers, tens, and the structure of the hundred board.
instructions:
1. Teen board: 'Make these numbers: 13, 17, 11, 19, 15.' Child forms each.
2. 'What does 15 mean?' (One ten and five ones.) Build with beads to verify.
3. Ten board: 'Count by tens: 10, 20, 30...' Child forms each number.
4. 'What comes between 20 and 40?' (30!) 'Between 50 and 70?' (60!)
5. Hundred board: fill in just the first row (1-10) and the tens column (10, 20, 30... 100).
6. 'What number is at row 3, column 5?' (35 — not expected to know this; just exploration.)
7. Final challenge: 'Count from 1 to 100!' Child counts aloud, using the hundred board if needed.

slides.heading: Q1 Math Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this big title! It says we're going to play a math game and practice numbers that are a little bigger, like teeny tiny numbers, and even numbers up to 100! Let's get ready for some super math fun.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up all three boards. This is a comprehensive review of Q1 number sense.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these cool boards and little beads! We have a special board for teen numbers, another for groups of ten, and a big board with numbers all the way up to 100. We'll use these to help us count and learn about numbers, just like we're building with blocks!

slides.text: Teen board: 'Make 13!' Child slides in the 3. 'What does 13 mean?' One ten and three ones.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first we're going to use this teen board! See how there's a long piece and then some little ones? We need to make the number 13. That means we need one long piece for ten and three little pieces for the ones. You can do it!

slides.text: Ten board: 'Count by tens!' Child forms: 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's play with the ten board! We're going to count by groups of ten. That means we say 10, then another 10 makes 20, and another 10 makes 30! It's like counting big stacks of cookies!

slides.text: Hundred board: 'Put in the first row: 1 through 10. Now put in the last column: 10, 20, 30...'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this big hundred board! We're going to fill in the first row, from number 1 all the way to 10. Then, we'll fill in the numbers that go straight down, like 10, 20, 30, all the way to 100! It's like drawing a big number ladder.

slides.text: 'Can you count from 1 all the way to 100? Use the board if you need it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try a super challenge! Can you count all the way from number 1 to number 100? You can look at the big board to help you remember the numbers. Take your time, you're doing great!

slides.prompt: Count from 1 to 100! You can use the hundred board to help. Then tell me: what's your favorite number and why?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you're counting to 100! That's amazing! Now, what's your most favorite number from all the ones we counted, and why do you like it so much? I can't wait to hear!

slides.text: 'You can count to 100! You know teens, tens, and the whole hundred board. What a mathematician you've become!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count to 100, form teen/ten numbers, and demonstrate understanding of place value?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You counted all the way to 100, and you learned about teen numbers and tens too! You are such a super mathematician, just like a grown-up! I'm so proud of you!

parent_notes: Counting to 100 is a major milestone for the primary child. Some children can rattle off the numbers by rote; the real question is whether they understand what the numbers mean. The teen and ten boards test this understanding: does the child know that 15 means 'one ten and five more'? If the child can count to 100 and understands teen numbers concretely, they're well-prepared for Q2's work with addition and the decimal system. If they struggle with the sequence in the 70s, 80s, or 90s, that's very common — these decades sound different from how they're structured.

title: Q1 Culture Review — Our World and Its People
description: Review of cultural studies from Q1: grace and courtesy, celebrations around the world (Diwali, Chinese New Year, Holi), and the diversity of human cultures. Creating a 'celebrations around the world' page.
instructions:
1. 'This quarter we learned about celebrations from different countries. Let's remember them all!'
2. Review Diwali: 'Where? What do people do?' (India — lights, diyas, sweets, new beginnings.)
3. Review Chinese New Year: 'Where? What traditions?' (China — red decorations, dragons, red envelopes.)
4. Review Holi: 'Where? What happens?' (India — colored powder, spring celebration, joy.)
5. Grace and courtesy: 'What table manners have we learned? How do we set the table?'
6. Create a 'Celebrations Around the World' poster: draw each celebration with its key symbol.
7. 'Every culture has beautiful traditions. Learning about them helps us understand each other.'

slides.heading: Q1 Culture Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Q1 Culture Review," and "Celebrations Around the World." That means we get to remember all the super fun parties and special days we learned about from different places!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all materials from previous cultural lessons. Have the globe ready for locating countries.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our special project today, we need some things! See this big paper? That's our poster paper. We'll use these colorful pencils to draw, and we have our old pictures to help us remember. Oh, and look, a globe! That's to help us find where all these celebrations happen.

slides.text: 'We learned about celebrations from around the world! How many can you remember?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's start thinking! We learned about so many cool celebrations from different countries. Can you remember any of them? Let's try to think of all the fun ones we talked about!

slides.text: 'Diwali — the Festival of Lights! Where is it celebrated?' Find India on the globe. 'What do people light?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This next part is about Diwali! Do you remember where Diwali is celebrated? It's in a country called India. People there light up pretty little lamps called diyas, like tiny candles, to celebrate new beginnings.

slides.text: 'Chinese New Year — what color is everywhere?' (Red!) 'And Holi — what do people throw?' (Colored powder!)
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about Chinese New Year! What color do you see everywhere when they celebrate? That's right, red! And for Holi, remember how much fun it was to think about all the colorful powder people throw?

slides.text: 'Let's also remember our grace and courtesy: setting the table, being kind, taking turns.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We also learned how to be super polite and kind! Remember how we learned to set the table nicely and how to take turns and use our nice words? That's all part of being a good friend and a good person!

slides.prompt: Create a poster showing all three celebrations. Draw a diya for Diwali, a lantern for Chinese New Year, and colorful handprints for Holi!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our amazing poster! We're going to draw a little light for Diwali, maybe a pretty lantern for Chinese New Year, and lots of colorful handprints for Holi! It's going to be so beautiful!

slides.text: 'People all over the world celebrate with light, color, food, and family. Isn't that beautiful?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all three celebrations and describe at least one tradition from each?
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it amazing how people everywhere love to celebrate with bright lights, fun colors, yummy food, and being with their families? We learned so much about how everyone is special and has wonderful traditions!

parent_notes: Cultural studies in Montessori are about building respect and curiosity for human diversity. At this age, the child isn't expected to understand the religious or historical contexts deeply — they absorb the sensory experiences (bright colors, special foods, music) and the universal themes (family, joy, new beginnings). The poster becomes a visual reference that reinforces learning. If the child has particularly latched onto one celebration, consider exploring it more deeply in Q2 with books, cooking, or music. Connection to real people from these cultures (friends, neighbors, community members) makes the learning authentic.

title: Read-Aloud: Whistle for Willie
description: Reading Ezra Jack Keats' story about Peter (from The Snowy Day) trying to learn to whistle. A story about persistence, practice, and the joy of finally mastering a new skill.
instructions:
1. 'Remember Peter from The Snowy Day? Today he's trying to learn something new — WHISTLING!'
2. Read the story. Peter tries and tries but can't whistle for his dog Willie.
3. He tries while walking, while spinning, while wearing his father's hat.
4. 'Has there ever been something you tried really hard to do but couldn't yet?'
5. When Peter finally whistles: celebrate! 'He practiced and practiced and he DID IT!'
6. After reading: try whistling together! (Many kindergartners can't whistle yet — and that's the point.)
7. 'Some things take lots of practice. That's okay. You'll get there!'
materials_needed: Whistle for Willie by Ezra Jack Keats

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Whistle for Willie by Ezra Jack Keats
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the name of the book we're going to read today. It's about a little boy named Peter, and he's trying to learn something new and fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably. This connects to The Snowy Day from Week 7 — same character!
slides.mascot_explanation: We need our special book for today, "Whistle for Willie." Remember Peter from "The Snowy Day"? He's back in this story, and we're going to sit down and read all about his adventure.

slides.text: 'Peter is back! But today he has a problem — he wants to whistle for his dog Willie, but he CAN'T!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh look, it's Peter again! In this story, Peter really, really wants to learn how to whistle for his dog, Willie. But it's a little tricky, and he can't do it yet!

slides.text: Read with empathy for Peter's frustration. He tries SO hard. Notice Keats' collage artwork again.
slides.mascot_explanation: Peter is trying super hard to whistle, but it's not working. We can feel how he feels when something is hard, but we'll keep reading to see what happens.

slides.text: The moment Peter finally whistles: 'HE DID IT! Willie came running!' Let the joy sink in.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Peter finally did it! He learned how to whistle, and his dog Willie came running to him! Isn't that exciting when you finally learn something new?

slides.prompt: Can YOU whistle? Let's try! Pucker your lips and blow gently. If it doesn't work yet, that's just like Peter — keep practicing!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's our turn to try! Let's pucker up our lips and make a little blowing sound, just like Peter. If we can't whistle yet, that's okay, because Peter had to practice a lot too!

slides.text: 'Peter kept trying even when it was hard. That's called PERSISTENCE. What are YOU practicing right now?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child connect Peter's persistence to their own learning experiences?
slides.mascot_explanation: Peter worked so hard to learn how to whistle, and he didn't give up! That's called being persistent. What's something you are practicing right now that you want to get really good at?

parent_notes: This book is perfectly placed at the end of Q1 because it mirrors the child's own experience of working hard to master new skills — reading, writing, counting, cutting. Peter's persistence is the same quality that has carried the child through 9 weeks of Montessori work. Most 4-5 year olds can't whistle, which makes the attempted whistling activity both humorous and poignant. Don't pressure the child to actually whistle — the point is that some skills take time, and that's okay. Connect to other 'Peter' books by Keats for a character study.

title: Q1 Sensorial Review — Knobbed Cylinders Challenge
description: Review of all four blocks of Knobbed Cylinders with a challenge: combining two blocks simultaneously. This tests the child's visual discrimination and problem-solving by requiring attention to two dimensions at once.
instructions:
1. 'You've mastered each cylinder block alone. Today's challenge: TWO BLOCKS at once!'
2. Remove all cylinders from Block 1 and Block 2. Mix them on the mat.
3. Child must sort and replace all cylinders into the correct block and hole.
4. This requires noticing both diameter AND height simultaneously.
5. If successful, try Blocks 3 and 4 combined.
6. Ultimate challenge (if ready): all 4 blocks mixed — 40 cylinders to sort!
7. Celebrate the child's growing ability to notice subtle differences.

slides.heading: Sensorial Challenge
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to do a super fun challenge with our special knobs and cylinders today! It's like a puzzle for our eyes to make everything fit just right.

slides.setup_instructions: Start with just Blocks 1 and 2. Remove all cylinders and mix them on the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the special wooden blocks with knobs and lots of little round pieces called cylinders! We also have a big mat for our work. We'll start with just two of the blocks, and we'll take all the little cylinders out and mix them up like a treasure hunt!

slides.text: 'You've done each block by itself. Today let's mix TWO blocks together! Can you sort them all out?'
slides.mascot_explanation: You are so good at putting the cylinders back by themselves! Today, we get to be super detectives and put TWO blocks of cylinders back together at the same time. It's a special challenge just for you!

slides.text: Remove all cylinders from Blocks 1 and 2. Mix them up. 'Now put every cylinder back in its right hole!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's take all the little round pieces out of these two blocks and mix them up on the mat. Now, your job is to be a super sorter and find the perfect spot for each little cylinder back in its own special hole.

slides.text: Watch: the child must decide which BLOCK each cylinder belongs to, then which HOLE within that block.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like a super-duper puzzle! You have to look very, very closely to see which block each cylinder belongs to, and then find the exact hole that fits it perfectly, just like magic!

slides.text: If the child finishes easily: 'Amazing! Want to try blocks 3 and 4?' Or even all four mixed!
slides.mascot_explanation: You are doing such a great job! If you finish these two blocks super fast, we can try mixing even more blocks together. Maybe we can even mix all four blocks to make the biggest puzzle ever!

slides.prompt: Sort all the mixed cylinders back into their correct blocks and holes. Use your eyes and hands to notice the size differences!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for the big puzzle! Let's use our super-sharp eyes and careful hands to put all these mixed-up cylinders back into their homes. We need to find the right block and the right spot for every single one!

slides.text: 'Your eyes have become so sharp! You can see differences that most people don't even notice.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly sort cylinders from 2 combined blocks into their correct positions?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Your eyes are like super-powered magnifying glasses now! You can see tiny differences and put everything in its perfect place, all by yourself! You are so smart!

parent_notes: Combining cylinder blocks is a classic Montessori extension that dramatically increases the difficulty. With one block, the child only considers one dimension (e.g., height varies while diameter stays constant). With two blocks mixed, they must consider two dimensions simultaneously — a cognitive leap. Most children find this challenging and exciting. If the child places a cylinder in the wrong hole, they'll notice because another cylinder won't fit later — this built-in error control is the genius of Montessori materials. Let the child discover and correct errors without your intervention.

title: Metal Insets — Review and Favorite Designs
description: Review of the Metal Insets for pencil control and artistic expression. The child creates a complex design using multiple inset shapes, demonstrating improved hand control and creative design skills developed over Q1.
instructions:
1. Review the Metal Insets: show the child all available shapes.
2. 'Today you'll create a DESIGN using at least 3 different shapes. Plan before you start!'
3. Demonstrate: overlay one shape on another to create a complex design.
4. Child traces shapes, then fills in with colored pencils using parallel lines.
5. Encourage different fill patterns: horizontal lines in one section, vertical in another, diagonal in another.
6. The focus is on staying within the lines and using controlled, even strokes.
7. Display the finished design. Compare to early Q1 work: 'See how much your hand control has improved!'
materials_needed: Early Q1 metal inset work for comparison (if saved)

slides.heading: Metal Insets
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play with our special shapes called Metal Insets and make a super cool picture today! It's a review to see all the amazing things you can do with them.

slides.setup_instructions: Set out all available insets. Have plenty of colored pencils. Find early Q1 work if saved.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our art supplies ready! We need some of our metal shapes, some nice paper, and your colorful pencils. Make sure we have at least three different shapes to use for our picture.

slides.text: 'Choose at least 3 different shapes. You're going to create a beautiful, complex design!'
slides.mascot_explanation: For our amazing design, we need to pick at least three different shapes from our box. Think about which ones you want to put together to make a fancy picture!

slides.text: 'Trace the first shape. Now OVERLAP a second shape on top. See the interesting areas where they cross?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's trace one shape onto the paper. After that, we'll put another shape right on top of it, like a little surprise! See how the shapes make new spaces where they meet?

slides.text: 'Fill each section with a different color. Use PARALLEL lines — lines that go the same direction and never touch.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We get to color in all the spaces we made! Pick a color for each space and draw lines that all go the same way, like little train tracks next to each other.

slides.text: 'In this section, try horizontal lines. In that section, vertical. In another, diagonal!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try drawing our lines in different directions! We can draw lines going sideways, or up and down, or even slanted like a slide! Pick a different direction for each part of your picture.

slides.prompt: Create your most beautiful design ever! Use at least 3 shapes and 4 colors. Take your time with the fill lines — try to stay inside the shapes!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make your most beautiful design! Use at least three shapes and four colors, and try your very best to keep your lines inside the shapes. Take your time and have fun being creative!

slides.text: 'Compare this to your first metal inset work. See how much more controlled your hand is? That's GROWTH!'
slides.mastery_check: Has the child's line control visibly improved since early Q1? Can they fill shapes with reasonably parallel lines?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this wonderful picture you made! See how your lines are so neat and steady? You have gotten so much better at drawing inside the lines since we first started. You've grown so much!

parent_notes: The Metal Insets are specifically designed to develop the fine motor control needed for writing. By now, the child should show visible improvement in line quality compared to their first attempts in Week 1. The parallel fill lines build the wrist and finger control needed for letter formation. Overlapping shapes creates a design that looks like stained glass — it's beautiful and motivating. If you saved early work, the comparison is powerful and builds the child's growth mindset. These designs make lovely cards or gifts, giving the work purpose beyond practice.

title: Q1 Math Review — Addition and Partners of 10
description: Review of addition concepts introduced in Week 8. The child revisits combining number rods and practices the partners of 10, reinforcing these foundational arithmetic concepts.
instructions:
1. 'Let's review our addition work! Remember, addition means putting numbers TOGETHER.'
2. Warm-up: 'What's 2 and 1?' Child combines rods. (3!) 'What's 3 and 2?' (5!)
3. Partners of 5: 'Tell me all the ways to make 5.' 4+1, 3+2, 2+3, 1+4, 5+0.
4. Partners of 10 staircase: build it again. 9+1, 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5.
5. Quick fire: 'If I have 7, how many more to make 10?' Child finds the 3-rod.
6. 'If I have 4, how many more to make 10?' Child finds the 6-rod.
7. Oral: 'I have 8, I need ___ more to make 10.' (2!) Repeat with different numbers.

slides.heading: Q1 Math Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun math page! We're going to play with numbers today and learn about putting them together, like building with blocks! It's called addition, and we'll also learn about special number friends that make 10.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out all rods. The child will build the partners of 10 staircase again.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these colorful number rods! We have them all here, from the little red one to the super long purple one. We'll use these special rods on our big mat to help us see how numbers fit together, like puzzle pieces.

slides.text: 'Addition means putting together! Quick: 2 and 1 makes?' Child combines rods. '3!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to start with addition! Remember, adding means putting things together. Let's see, if we put the little red rod (that's 2) and the tiny green rod (that's 1) together, what do we get? Yay, it makes a 3-rod!

slides.text: 'All the ways to make 5: go!' Child builds: 4+1, 3+2, 2+3, 1+4.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about making the number 5. We can use our rods to find different ways to build it! Can you show me how to make 5 using a 4-rod and a 1-rod? What about a 3-rod and a 2-rod? Let's find all the ways!

slides.text: 'Now the big one — partners of TEN!' Build the staircase: 9+1, 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super big one: making the number 10! We're going to build a tall staircase with our rods to show all the number friends that add up to 10. Let's put the 9-rod and the 1-rod together, then the 8-rod and the 2-rod, and see how they fit perfectly!

slides.text: 'Quick fire: I have 6, how many more to make 10?' Child finds the 4-rod. 'I have 3?' (7!)
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super quick game! If I have the 6-rod, how many more rods do we need to make it a 10-rod? Can you find the rod that fits right on top? That's right, it's the 4-rod! What about if you have the 3-rod? You need the 7-rod!

slides.prompt: Build the partners of 10 staircase. Then play quick fire: I say a number, you tell me its partner to make 10!
slides.mascot_explanation: We get to play for a little while now! We'll build our 10 staircase again, and then I'll say a number, and you tell me its partner to make 10. You're going to be a number detective, finding all the missing pieces! You can do it!

slides.text: 'You know your partners of 10 like a pro! These will help you with math for years to come.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child state at least 3 partners of 10 without using rods?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are a math superstar! You learned all the number friends that make 10, and you did it so fast! Those number friends will help you with all sorts of cool math things for a long, long time. You were so good at finding the missing rods!

parent_notes: Partners of 10 are worth revisiting again and again because they're the building blocks of mental arithmetic. A child who instantly knows that 7+3=10 can later solve 47+3=50, 70+30=100, and much more. The 'quick fire' game (you say a number, child says the partner) builds automatic recall. Start slowly and speed up as the child gains confidence. Some children will begin answering without the rods — this is the transition from concrete to abstract, and it's a major milestone. But keep the rods available; there's no rush to remove the concrete support.

title: Nature Walk — Seasonal Observation
description: A nature walk focused on observing seasonal characteristics and recording findings in the science journal. The child practices the scientific skills of observation, comparison, and documentation.
instructions:
1. 'Scientists observe the world carefully. Today we're going on a nature walk to see what's happening outside.'
2. Bring the science journal, pencil, a bag for collecting specimens.
3. Walk slowly. 'What do you notice about the trees? The ground? The sky? The animals?'
4. Collect specimens: interesting leaves, seeds, small stones, feathers.
5. Stop and listen: 'Close your eyes. What do you hear?' Record sounds.
6. Back inside: tape or draw specimens in the journal. Label with the date.
7. 'What season is it? How do you know? What clues did nature give us?'
8. Compare to Week 1 nature walk observations if available.

slides.heading: Nature Walk
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we're going on a special adventure outside called a "Nature Walk" to be nature detectives and see what's happening outside right now. We're going to look for clues about what season it is!

slides.setup_instructions: Dress for the weather. Bring all materials. Choose a route with diverse nature.
slides.mascot_explanation: To be super nature scientists, we need some special tools! We need our science journal to write and draw in, a pencil to help us, a bag for collecting cool treasures we find, some tape to stick them in our journal, and a magnifying glass to see tiny things up close. Ask a grown-up to help you get all these things ready and put on your outdoor clothes!

slides.text: 'We're going to observe nature like scientists! Look carefully at EVERYTHING. What do you notice?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, super scientist, let's go outside and look with our super-spy eyes! We need to look very, very carefully at everything we see – the tall trees, the wiggly worms, even the fluffy clouds. What do you notice that looks different outside today?

slides.text: 'Look at the trees. Are there leaves? Buds? Bare branches? What color are they?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at the trees! Are they wearing fuzzy green leaves, or maybe bright colors like red and yellow? Some trees might not have any leaves at all right now! We're looking for clues about what season it is.

slides.text: 'Listen! Close your eyes for 30 seconds. What sounds does nature make right now?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Shhh, listen super carefully! Close your eyes for a little bit and let your ears do the work. What sounds do you hear outside? Do you hear birds singing, or maybe the wind rustling through the leaves?

slides.text: 'Collect things that interest you: a special leaf, a seed, a feather. We'll put them in your journal!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the fun part – collecting treasures! Look around for anything interesting that nature left for us, like a pretty leaf, a tiny seed, or maybe even a soft feather. We'll put these special finds in our bag to take back with us.

slides.prompt: Back inside: tape your specimens in your journal. Draw anything you couldn't collect. Write the date and the season. What did you discover?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're back inside, super scientists! Let's take our treasures and carefully tape them into our journal. If you saw something really cool that you couldn't pick up, you can draw a picture of it! Then, let's write down today's date and tell everyone what season it is – how did you know?

slides.text: 'Scientists observe carefully and write down what they find — just like you did today! Nature changes with every season.'
