slides.mastery_check: Can the child make at least 3 specific observations about seasonal characteristics?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job being a nature scientist today! You looked and listened so carefully, just like real scientists do. You found clues and put them in your journal, showing everyone how much nature changes!

parent_notes: Nature walks are a cornerstone of Montessori science education. The key is SLOW observation — resist the urge to rush or cover lots of ground. Ten minutes in one spot, looking closely, yields more learning than a 30-minute walk. The science journal becomes a record of seasonal change; if you do this quarterly, the child can compare entries and see how nature transforms. A magnifying glass transforms any nature walk into an adventure — suddenly bark, leaves, and insects reveal incredible details. This walk also builds vocabulary: 'deciduous,' 'evergreen,' 'dormant,' 'buds.'

title: Music — Q1 Song Review and Rhythm Performance
description: Review of songs, rhythms, and musical concepts learned in Q1. The child demonstrates their musical vocabulary (loud/soft, high/low, fast/slow) and performs a short rhythm piece.
instructions:
1. 'Let's remember all the music we've learned this quarter!'
2. Sing together: review 3-4 favorite songs from Q1.
3. Musical vocabulary: 'Show me LOUD.' (Child claps loudly.) 'Show me soft.' (Gentle clap.)
4. 'Play me something HIGH.' (Child sings or plays a high note.) 'Now LOW.'
5. 'Clap something FAST.' 'Now SLOW.'
6. Rhythm review: echo-clap 4 different patterns. Child echoes each.
7. Child creates their own 8-beat rhythm piece using body percussion.
8. Performance! Child performs their rhythm piece for the family.
materials_needed: Optional: bells, drum, or other instruments from Q1

slides.heading: Q1 Music Review
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Q1 Music Review." That means we get to remember all the super fun music we learned at the beginning of the year! We're going to sing songs and make cool sounds together.

slides.setup_instructions: Clear a space for movement and performance. Have any instruments used during Q1 available.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our music time, we might need some special things! See that picture? It shows some instruments we might have used before. If you have any of those, like a shaker or a drum, let's get them ready! We also need a nice open space so we can move and dance while we sing.

slides.text: 'Let's sing our favorite songs from this quarter!' Sing 2-3 songs the child enjoyed most.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, singing time! The slide says we get to sing our favorite songs from this quarter. Let's pick out the ones that make you want to clap and dance the most! Singing together is so much fun.

slides.text: 'Show me: LOUD clap! Soft clap! FAST! Slow! HIGH singing! Low singing!' Child demonstrates each.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to show off how we use our voices and hands for music! Can you show me a LOUD clap? Great job! Now, a super soft, quiet clap. And can you sing a high note, like a little bird? Now try a low note, like a big bear! Let's also try clapping fast and then slow.

slides.text: Echo-clapping: 'Copy my rhythm!' Do 4 patterns. Can the child echo them all accurately?
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like a fun game! I'm going to clap a rhythm, and you copy me exactly. It's like we're musical echoes! We'll try four different patterns, and you can show me how well you can listen and copy.

slides.text: 'Now YOU create a rhythm! Use claps, knee pats, stomps — 8 beats. Practice it until you've got it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the music maker! The slide wants you to make your own special rhythm. You can clap your hands, pat your knees, or even stomp your feet! Try to make it 8 beats long, and practice it a few times until it sounds just right.

slides.prompt: Create your own 8-beat rhythm using body percussion. Practice it 3 times, then perform it for your family!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's performance time! You get to show off the super cool 8-beat rhythm you made all by yourself. Use your hands, your knees, and your feet to show everyone how great you are at making music. You practiced it, and now it's time to shine!

slides.text: 'You're a musician! You can sing, keep a beat, echo rhythms, and create your own music. Bravo!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate loud/soft, high/low, fast/slow, and create a simple rhythm pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: Bravo! You did it! You remembered all our songs, you showed me loud and soft, high and low, fast and slow, and you even made your very own rhythm! You are such a fantastic musician!

parent_notes: Music education at this age is about joy, expression, and the foundational concepts of sound. The musical vocabulary (dynamics: loud/soft, pitch: high/low, tempo: fast/slow) will serve the child throughout their musical life. The performance element is important: it builds confidence and gives the child a sense of accomplishment. Be an enthusiastic audience — applaud genuinely. If the child has shown particular interest in music this quarter, consider introducing a simple instrument like a recorder or ukulele in Q2. Singing together as a family is one of the best things you can do for your child's musical development.

title: Q1 Practical Life Review — Favorite Works
description: The child revisits their favorite practical life works from Q1 and demonstrates mastery. This celebration of skills highlights how much the child has grown in independence and competence over the quarter.
instructions:
1. 'This quarter you've learned so many things! Let's look at all your skills.'
2. Set up a 'skill stations' circuit: pouring, cutting, spreading, sewing, table setting, sweeping.
3. Child rotates through each station, performing the activity independently.
4. At each station, note: can the child do this without help? With confidence? With precision?
5. 'Which was your favorite work this quarter? Which was the hardest?'
6. The child chooses their favorite to demonstrate for a family member.
7. Celebrate: 'Look at everything you can do now that you couldn't do 9 weeks ago!'
materials_needed: Materials for all Q1 practical life activities

slides.heading: Q1 Practical Life
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Q1 Practical Life" and "Celebrate Your Skills!" That means we get to see all the super cool things you learned to do this quarter. We're going to have so much fun celebrating how smart and strong you are!

items: All Q1 practical life materials at stations
slides.setup_instructions: Set up 5-6 stations around the room with Q1 practical life activities.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these wonderful things! These are the special tools we'll use for our activities today. We have cups for pouring, maybe some safe scissors for cutting, and even a tiny broom for sweeping! We need to find all these special things to play with.

slides.text: 'Look at all these things you've learned! Let's visit each station and show what you can do.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to start! This says, "Let's visit each station and show what you can do." That means we're going to walk around and show off all the amazing skills you've learned, one by one. Let's go see what's first!

slides.text: Station 1: Pouring. 'Pour water from pitcher to glasses without spilling.' Station 2: Cutting. 'Cut a banana safely.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to try some fun things! First, we'll practice pouring water carefully from one cup to another, like a grown-up. Then, we'll use safe scissors to try cutting a yummy banana. It’s important to be careful and show how well you can do these jobs!

slides.text: Station 3: Spreading. 'Spread butter on bread.' Station 4: Sewing. 'Do a running stitch.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are more super skills we'll practice! We'll get to spread something yummy, like butter, onto bread. Then, we'll try a little bit of sewing to make a pretty stitch. You are so good at trying new things!

slides.text: Station 5: Table setting. 'Set a place.' Station 6: Sweeping. 'Sweep a small area.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're almost done with our skills! Next, we'll get to set a table so it looks nice and neat. And then, we'll use a little broom to sweep up any little messes. You are so good at helping out!

slides.prompt: Visit each station and do the activity. Then choose your FAVORITE and demonstrate it for someone in your family!
slides.mascot_explanation: It’s time to show off your best skills! We’ll go to each little spot and do the activity, just like we practiced. Then, you get to pick your absolute favorite thing you did and show it to someone special, like Mommy or Daddy!

slides.text: 'You can pour, cut, spread, sew, set the table, and sweep! In 9 weeks you've become so independent and capable!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform at least 4 of 6 practical life activities with confidence and minimal adult help?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Look at all the things you can do now – pouring, cutting, spreading, sewing, setting the table, and sweeping! You have become so independent and capable in just 9 weeks. I am so, so proud of you!

parent_notes: This review is a celebration, not a test. Watching the child rotate through skills they've developed over 9 weeks is emotional and inspiring. You'll likely notice that skills introduced early in the quarter (pouring, for example) are now effortless, while newer skills (cutting, sweeping) still require concentration. That's perfect — it shows the progression from conscious effort to automatic competence. The child choosing a favorite to demonstrate builds their sense of identity: 'I'm a person who can do things.' Take a video of the demonstrations — you'll treasure it later.

title: Independent Reading and Storytelling
description: The child reads independently and then creates their own story, dictating it to the parent. This lesson celebrates both the child's reading growth and their narrative imagination.
instructions:
1. Independent reading: child selects and reads 2-3 phonetic readers silently or aloud.
2. After each, retell: 'What happened in that story?'
3. 'Now YOU are going to be the AUTHOR! Tell me a story and I'll write it down.'
4. Child dictates a story (any topic). Parent writes exactly what the child says.
5. Read the story back to the child. 'YOU wrote this!'
6. Child illustrates their story.
7. Staple together as a mini-book: the child's first authored work.
8. Add to the reading log: 'Today I wrote my own book!'
materials_needed: Paper for the child's book (3-4 sheets folded and stapled)

slides.heading: Reading and Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! It says "Reading and Writing," and it also says "You're an Author!" That means today we get to be super smart readers and super creative story writers. We're going to do both things that make our brains grow big and strong!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare folded paper for a mini-book. Have phonetic readers available for independent reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the special things we need for our author adventure! We have some books here for you to read all by yourself. Then we have paper to make our very own book, a pencil to write with, and colorful crayons for drawing pictures. We even have a stapler to put our book all together at the end!

slides.text: 'Start by reading! Choose 2 books and read them yourself. I'll be right here if you need help.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time for you to be a super reader! Pick out two books that you like. You can read them by yourself, or if you want, you can read them out loud. I'll be right here to cheer you on!

slides.text: 'Now the exciting part: you're going to WRITE your own story! Tell me your story and I'll write your words down.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready for the best part – you get to be the author of your very own story! Think of anything you want to tell me, and I will write down every single word you say. It's like magic, your words will become a real story!

slides.text: Write the child's words exactly as spoken on each page of the mini-book. Read it back to them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now I get to help make your story super special. I will write down all the amazing words you tell me on the pages of your new book. Then, I'll read your whole story back to you so you can hear how wonderful it sounds!

slides.text: 'Now draw pictures for each page! Every author needs an illustrator — and you're BOTH!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every great book needs colorful pictures, and guess what? You get to draw them! You are the author *and* the illustrator, which means you get to make both the words and the pictures for your amazing story.

slides.prompt: Illustrate every page of your book. When it's done, read your book aloud to someone you love!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make your book beautiful with drawings! Look at each page and draw a picture for your story. When you're all done drawing, you can read your brand new book to someone you love, like Mommy or Daddy!

slides.text: 'You read books AND you wrote a book! You are a READER and an AUTHOR. What a way to end Quarter 1!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read independently, dictate a coherent story, and read back portions of their dictated text?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! You read books all by yourself, and you even wrote your very own book. You are a fantastic reader and a brilliant author, and that is super, super cool!

parent_notes: This lesson is a powerful culmination of Q1 language work. The child demonstrates reading skill (decoding phonetic readers) AND oral language skill (composing a narrative). Writing down the child's exact words — even grammatical errors — shows the child that their words matter and can be preserved. When you read the story back, the child sees their spoken words transformed into written text — a profound literacy moment. Some children will dictate elaborate fantasies; others will tell about their day. Both are valuable. Keep this first authored book forever — it's a treasure.

title: Q1 Math Celebration — Math Games
description: A fun, game-based review of all Q1 math concepts. The child plays math games that incorporate counting, numeral recognition, quantity matching, addition, and number patterns.
instructions:
1. 'Today is Math Game Day! We'll play 4 fun games.'
2. Game 1 — Number Hunt: hide number cards 1-20 around the room. Child finds them and puts in order.
3. Game 2 — Roll and Count: roll a die, count out that many objects. First to 20 wins.
4. Game 3 — Partners of 10 Memory: make cards with numbers 1-9. Turn 2 over. If they make 10, keep them!
5. Game 4 — Hundred Board Puzzle: remove 10 random tiles. Can the child figure out which ones are missing?
6. 'Which game was your favorite?'
7. Celebrate: 'You are a mathematician! Look how much math you know!'

slides.heading: Q1 Math Celebration
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's Math Game Day! We get to play lots of fun games today that help us practice all the super cool math things we learned. Get ready for some fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up each game in a different area. Hide number cards before starting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these fun things we need for our games! We have number cards with all the numbers on them, a bouncy die, little things to count, and special memory cards. Let's ask a grown-up to help us find them all so we can start playing!

slides.text: 'It's Math Game Day! We're going to play 4 different games that use everything you've learned!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play! Today we are going to play four awesome games that are like a super fun party for your brain. We'll use all the math you already know to play!

slides.text: Game 1: 'I hid numbers around the room! Find them all and put them in order from 1 to 20!'
slides.mascot_explanation: For our first game, we get to go on a number hunt! I've hidden numbers all around the room, and your job is to find them all. Then, we'll put them in order from the smallest number to the biggest number, like lining up your toys!

slides.text: Game 2: 'Roll the die, count out that many. Keep adding. First person to reach 20 wins!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This next game is super exciting! We get to roll this special die, and then we count out that many little objects. We keep adding more and more until we reach the number 20 – wow, that's a big number!

slides.text: Game 3: 'Flip two cards. Do they make 10? If yes, keep them! (7 and 3? Yes! 4 and 2? No.)'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to play a matching game with these cards. We flip two cards over, and if the numbers on them add up to 10, we get to keep them! It's like finding a special pair.

slides.prompt: Game 4: Hundred Board Puzzle! I removed 10 tiles. Study the board and figure out which numbers are missing!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this puzzle! Some of the number squares are missing, and we need to figure out which numbers are gone. Let's look closely at the numbers we see and guess which ones are hiding!

slides.text: 'You played games using counting, ordering, adding, and patterns. Math is fun! You're ready for Quarter 2!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child successfully participate in all 4 games, demonstrating Q1 math skills in a game context?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You played all the games and used your counting, ordering, and adding superpowers! You are such a great mathematician, and you're all ready for more math fun!

parent_notes: Ending Q1 with games reinforces the idea that math is enjoyable, not just work. Each game assesses a different skill: number sequencing (hunt), counting and one-to-one correspondence (roll and count), partners of 10 (memory), and number recognition (hundred board puzzle). The game context also reveals how well the child has internalized concepts — can they apply their knowledge when it's embedded in play? If the child struggles with any game, it tells you which area needs continued practice in Q2. But today, prioritize FUN. The child should enter Q2 feeling confident and excited about math.

title: Q1 Reflection — Our Learning Journey
description: A reflective session where the child and parent look back on everything learned in Quarter 1. Creating a Q1 portfolio page and setting intentions for Quarter 2.
instructions:
1. 'Let's look at everything we did this quarter! I'm so proud of you.'
2. Flip through the child's work: Continent Book, science journal, metal inset designs, reading log, math work.
3. 'What did you learn that surprised you? What was your favorite lesson?'
4. 'What was the hardest thing you did? How did you get through it?'
5. Create a 'Q1 Accomplishments' page: child draws or writes their proudest achievements.
6. 'What would you like to learn about next quarter?'
7. Take a photo of the child with their Q1 work spread out. Frame or save it.
8. 'Quarter 2 starts next week! You're ready!'

slides.heading: Q1 Reflection
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Q1 Reflection" and "Our Learning Journey." That means we get to look back at all the super fun things we did in the first part of our school year, like a special adventure!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather all the child's work from Q1: journals, books, art, portfolios. Spread them out.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all our amazing work! We have our books, our drawings, and all sorts of special papers. We also need some paper and colorful pencils to draw with, and a camera to take a picture of our wonderful work!

slides.text: 'Look at ALL of this! YOU did all of this work. Let's remember together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at all these special things we made! You worked so hard, and I'm so proud of you for learning and doing all of this. We're going to remember all the fun we had together.

slides.text: 'What was your FAVORITE thing we learned?' 'What was the HARDEST?' Listen with genuine interest.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about our favorite parts. What was the most exciting thing we learned or did? And was there anything that felt a little tricky? It's okay if some things were hard, we learn best when we try our best!

slides.text: 'Draw your proudest accomplishments on this page. What are you most proud of?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our special "Q1 Accomplishments" page! You get to draw pictures of the things you did that made you feel super proud. What was your very best moment from this first part of school?

slides.text: 'What do you want to learn next? What are you curious about?' Write their answers down.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to think about what's coming next! What new things are you excited to learn about in our next part of school? What makes you curious and want to know more?

slides.prompt: Create your Q1 Accomplishments page. Draw pictures of your 3 proudest moments from this quarter!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our special page! Let's draw three pictures of the things you are most proud of doing in our first learning journey. You can draw anything you like that shows how amazing you are!

slides.text: 'You've grown so much in 9 weeks! You can read, count, pour, cut, sew, and so much more. I'm SO proud of you!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify specific things they've learned and express pride in their accomplishments?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You've learned so many new things, like reading and counting and doing all sorts of creative projects. I am so, so proud of how much you've grown and all the wonderful things you can do!

parent_notes: Reflection is a powerful metacognitive skill that even young children can practice. Looking back at their work helps the child see their own growth — something they often don't notice in the day-to-day. The questions about 'hardest' and 'favorite' develop self-awareness. Writing down the child's hopes for Q2 honors their voice and can guide your planning. The photo of the child with their Q1 work becomes a milestone memory. This ritual — quarterly reflection — teaches the child that learning is a journey with markers of progress. It builds intrinsic motivation and a growth mindset.

title: Read-Aloud: The Very Busy Spider
description: Reading Eric Carle's story about a spider who stays focused on building her web despite constant interruptions from farm animals. A perfect Q1 closing story about perseverance and completing important work.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'A spider is building her web. But all the animals want her to come play!'
2. Read the story. Notice the repetition: each animal asks the spider to do something, but 'the spider didn't answer. She was very busy spinning her web.'
3. Let the child join in on the repeated refrain.
4. Feel the raised web on the page (if using the original edition with textured illustrations).
5. When the web is finished: 'She did it! She built the whole web even though everyone kept interrupting!'
6. After reading: 'Sometimes when we're doing important work, people want us to stop. What did the spider do? She kept going!'
7. 'You've been like the spider this quarter — you stayed focused and did amazing work!'
materials_needed: The Very Busy Spider by Eric Carle

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Very Busy Spider by Eric Carle
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to read a special book called "The Very Busy Spider." It's going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably. If you have the raised-print edition, let the child feel the web after reading.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's the only thing we need for our story time! It's the book, "The Very Busy Spider." We'll sit close together and read it.

slides.text: Cover: 'This spider has an important job to do — build her web! But everyone keeps asking her to play.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See the picture on the front? It shows a little spider with a big job to do! She needs to build her web, but all her friends want her to play instead.

slides.text: Read with the repeating pattern. Each animal asks. 'The spider didn't answer. She was very busy spinning her web.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we'll read the story together. Listen for what the animals ask the spider, and remember what the spider says when she's busy. Can you say "She was very busy spinning her web"?

slides.text: When the web is done: 'Look! She finished her beautiful web! And she caught a fly for her dinner!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! The spider finished her beautiful web! She worked so hard, and now she can eat her yummy dinner.

slides.prompt: 'The spider was FOCUSED. She had a goal and she didn't give up. What's something YOU worked hard on this quarter?'
slides.mascot_explanation: The spider was so focused on her job, wasn't she? What's something you worked really, really hard on lately? Maybe building a tall tower or drawing a picture?

slides.text: 'Just like the spider, you stayed busy and did amazing work this quarter. You should be very proud!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the spider's persistence and connect it to their own learning this quarter?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today, just like the busy spider! You stayed focused and learned so much this quarter. I'm super proud of you!

parent_notes: This is the perfect Q1 closing book. The spider's persistence mirrors what the child has done all quarter: showing up, doing the work, staying focused even when it was hard. The repetitive structure is comforting and satisfying, and the payoff (a completed web) parallels the child's Q1 portfolio of completed work. Eric Carle's collage illustrations connect to art concepts the child has learned. The raised-print edition (where you can feel the web growing page by page) is a sensorial experience worth seeking out. End Q1 on this note of pride and persistence.
